title: 111_hr6207
content: The "Rural Flood Mitigation and Recovery Act of 2010" allows the Secretary of the Army to recommend flood damage reduction projects in disaster-prone areas based on the non-Federal interest's demonstration of the project's necessity for long-term economic viability. The term "flood prone disaster area" is defined as an area designated as such by the President under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. SEC. 3 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include a new section 428, focusing on flood prone disaster areas. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include a new section 428, which focuses on determining flood prone disaster areas and providing special rules for assistance in those areas. The President will determine if an area qualifies as a flood prone disaster area if it has experienced at least 2 other major disasters due to flooding in the 5-year period preceding the declaration of a major disaster. Assistance under this Act will apply to the designated flood prone disaster area. The President will increase the federal share for hazard mitigation measures in flood prone disaster areas to 90% or 100% if additional funding is necessary for long-term economic viability. Additionally, the President will increase the total contributions for hazard mitigation measures to 20% and 20% from the original 15% and 20% specified in the Act. The President will increase federal contributions for repair, restoration, and replacement of damaged facilities in flood prone disaster areas to 90% or 100% if additional funding is necessary for long-term economic viability. The total contributions for hazard mitigation measures will be increased to 20% and 25% from the original 15% and 20% specified in the Act. Flood Prone Disaster Area Task Forces will be established in each State with flood prone disaster areas. The President will establish task forces in flood-prone disaster areas to coordinate response activities involving relevant Federal and State agencies. SEC. 4 amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to specify timing requirements for hazard mitigation contributions after a major disaster. SEC. 5 addresses federal assistance to individuals and households. SEC. 5 amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to consider economic impact and previous disasters when providing assistance to individuals and households affected by a major disaster. SEC. 6 amends title 23 to allow for emergency relief efforts to be extended beyond 180 days in case of inclement weather or flooding. SEC. 7 introduces a pilot program for the repair, restoration, and replacement of damaged facilities. During a 2-year period, the President will select 3 major disasters for modified response procedures. This involves making contributions for repair projects based on selected bids. A report on the benefits of these procedures must be submitted to Congress within 30 months of enactment. The use of modified response procedures will be evaluated for benefits and any resulting overpayments. SEC. 8. INDIAN TRIBE DISASTER RESPONSE MANAGEMENT PILOT PROGRAM. The President shall establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program, selecting 5 Indian tribes based on past major disaster declarations. Selected tribes will be treated as states for participation. The President will establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program, selecting 5 tribes based on past major disaster declarations. Selected tribes will be treated as states for participation, allowing them to request disaster declarations and manage response activities. The program lasts for 5 years, during which technical assistance and grants will be provided to ensure preparedness. The President will establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program for 5 selected tribes to manage disaster response activities. A report on the program's results and recommendations, including the possibility of making it permanent for all Indian tribes, will be submitted to Congress within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency can provide grants to States for studying and prioritizing road projects for disaster preparedness. A report on improving communication and recommendations for hazard mitigation assistance will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 11 of the Act requires the President to submit a report to Congress within 6 months detailing the use of contributions for hazard mitigation projects. The report should assess effectiveness, identify obstacles, provide recommendations for improvement, and describe the interaction between different mitigation efforts. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of disaster relief processes under the Stafford Act in assisting distressed communities, including Indian tribes. A report will be submitted to Congress within 12 months. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the paperwork reduction for hazard mitigation projects under the Stafford Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 12 months on the effectiveness of disaster relief processes and recommendations for streamlining application processes for hazard mitigation activities.
